intro: Halosarcia syncarpa, commonly known as the sea holly, is a flowering plant belonging to the legume family, Fabaceae. It is native to coastal regions of southern Africa, where it thrives in sandy, saline soils. The plant is characterized by its spiny, glandular stems and clusters of small, blue or violet flowers. Its leaves are trifoliate, with each leaflet being hairy and adapted to reduce water loss. Halosarcia syncarpa is well-suited to arid environments and plays a role in stabilizing coastal dunes.
